column1: Ways to Support Minnesota’s Immigrant Communities
as ICE Activity Escalates
Minneapolis St Paul Magazine (January 2026)
Food drives, fundraisers, trainings, restaurant specials, and other resources to support immigrant communities during ICE's massive Operation Metro Surge
Trainings and Know-Your-Rights Info

Thousands of people have either already completed or signed up for the Monarca network’s legal observer trainings—they fill to capacity quickly, but keep an eye on the website, as new ones are often added. Some of the resources (like signage that were previously available on their website, are no longer accessible, though they still have their rapid response line (612-441-2881).

Unidos MN has a thorough “know your rights” resource walking through a number of situations, i.e. if ICE shows up at your home or workplace, if you’re detained by the police, what documents to carry, etc.
The Star Tribune has compiled a great resource detailing what, exactly, ICE agents can and can’t do, and what rights legal observers have during encounters.
Local writer Naomi Kritzer has an excellent guide with lots of detailed information on how to get trained, get connected, and do community defense in safe and smart ways.
If You or Your Loved Ones Are Affected by ICE Activity

The State of Minnesota has a very thorough webpage with various resources, from know-your-rights information to legal aid and health care information. If you're looking for a broad range of services and legal information, head there.
If you are trying to find someone who has been detained by ICE, here’s a link to the Online Detainee Locator System.

Neighborhood House in St. Paul's West Side neighborhood, just across the way from El Burrito Mercado, offers a range of services: two food shelves, family service centers, housing stability, and more.
Leo's Tow is helping to return the abandoned vehicles of people who have been taken by ICE to their families, reach out via Facebook or at 651-703-4914 for help.

A number of grocery stores around the metro are offering free food delivery (and if you're not directly impacted by ICE activity and are able to go out and shop, they're great businesses to support). Also listed are local mutual aid organizations offering home delivery.
All three locations of Colonial Market—in Minneapolis, North Minneapolis, and Bloomington—are offering home delivery. Call 651-508-0256.
Home delivery from Valerie’s Carniceria is back up and running; 613-823-4400.
Bymore Mercado in St. Paul continues to offer free food delivery.
Alborada Market is once again offering grocery delivery; schedule at 612-276-9552 ext 1.
Community Aid Network offers home delivery; request via the link.

Dios Habla Hoy church in south Minneapolis offers food delivery; you can request a delivery via this link. If you need help quickly, you can text via 612-703-2992, 612-432-7786, 952-917-9520, or 952-200-0889.
Calvary Food Shelf does home deliveries, if you're not able to pick up food on-location call 612-285-3876.
La Viña Church in Burnsville has free groceries, you can sign up here.
New Generation Church is also doing food delivery and rent support.
Rent Support

Big shoutout to organizer Ashley Fairbanks, who created Stand With Minnesota, an invaluable resource for both finding and offering support to neighbors as ICE's metro operation continues. You'll find a section on rent support fundraisers there, but for added visibility I'm going to cross-post them here, plus others I find:
Powderhorn Park Neighborhood Rent Relief Fund
CANDO Rent Relief Fund
Collective Care Fund
Cempazúchitl Collective
Sky Without Limits/Cielo San Limites
Colectiva Bilingüe’s shared rent relief fund
Rent Relief for MPS Families
Rent Support for Bancroft Families
West Side Rent Assistance
Mutual Aid Funds and Organizations to Donate To

It's been amazing to see the support for Renee Good's family in the week since her death at the hands of ICE agent Jonathan Ross. But if you have the resources, there's also a huge need for mutual aid for the families of the now reported thousands of people across the metro who have been detained by ICE.

These fundraisers can be hard to track down via search, but I'll continue to list what I find here: for the Ponce family; for Sing and family; for a Minnesota family of nine; for Christian Rivera and family; for Donaldo's family; for Zurzya Sanchez's family; for Karla Lopez's family; for Josefina and Gabriel; for a local family separated by ICE; for a family of four unable to work; for Gilberto Avillar's family; for Jairo Pitalasig's family; for a family whose young cousin was detained; for a group of seven local affected families; for ChongLy Scott Thao's family; for Milton, who needs to access his medication for ankylosing spondylitis; and for Nouland, a veteran who had a stroke after being assaulted by ICE.

Minnesota Immigrant Rights Action Committee has continued its food card fundraiser to help get groceries and necessities to families forced into hiding, parents kept away from work and kids from school. You can donate here.

Community Aid Network is an excellent evergreen mutual aid organization—you can donate directly, or sign up to volunteer for food distribution and deliveries at Bethel Lutheran Church via the link here.
Leo's Tow, which (as mentioned above) is helping to return the abandoned vehicles of people who have been taken by ICE to their families, you can Venmo them at @leostowingmn.

The Women's Foundation of Minnesota runs an Immigrant Rapid Response Fund that, in the organization's words, "ensures that resources move quickly, responsibly, and with community accountability to trusted organizations responding to immigration-related emergencies across Minnesota." It's a good general fund to donate to.
The Immigrant Law Center is offering legal support to countless people detained by ICE in Minnesota—you can donate here.

Neighbors in southwest Minneapolis and St. Paul's West Side neighborhood are fundraising to support their neighbors with rental assistance, food delivery, healthcare access and services, transportation, and legal support services.

A group of parents are providing direct support to the teachers and staff at a Longfellow neighborhood school—they're distributing funds for groceries, an on-site pantry, and emergency rent/utilities. You can donate via Venmo; the school's name is kept private for protection.
Northern Coffeeworks is supporting a mutual aid request from a neighbor supporting 10 immigrant families with weekly food deliveries and basic essentials.
Smitten Kitten is doing amazing work and helping amplify various mutual aid fundraisers; keep an eye on their Instagram. Though they're no longer accepting donations of goods at their Uptown shop,
you can find a link to donate directly to Isuroon, which is supporting Somali families with essential goods, in their bio; they're also fundraising to support a local family separated by ICE.

Beyond Beurre Blanc, AKA local independent food critic Kirstie Kimball, is also an excellent resource for information on how to continue supporting local families as 1) ICE operations continue and 2) food stamps and other hunger relief programs are yet again frozen in Minnesota. Stay tuned for updates via Instagram.
Food (and Essential Goods) Drives
These restaurants, cafes, and businesses are currently drop-off sites for donations to various food drives. Check social media ahead of time as hours and dates for drop-off may change:
Karol Coffee
Lynette
Pow Wow Grounds
Picnic Linden Hills
Little Bird Delicatessen
Bad Weather Brewing Co.
Bang Brewing is collecting new or gently used art supplies for families sheltering at home.
Workhorse Coffee Bar
Wandering Leaf Brewing Co.
Bad Rooster
Easy Day Cafe and North Star Deli are collaborating on a Kingfield food drive.
Hold the Wheat and Sift Gluten-Free are teaming up for a gluten-free food drive)!
Both the Edina and Minneapolis locations of the Grind spin studio through January 22 (both essential items and financial donations are accepted, all will support a local elementary school).
Seward Cafe is accepting donations on January 22, and distributing those donations out of the cafe on January 23.

Here's a list of places you can volunteer with for food packing and delivery: Sanneh Foundation, Dios Habla Hoy, Calvary Food Shelf, La Viña Church, Twin Cities Food Justice (volunteer intake is paused at the moment but check back soon).

Modern Times and Amigos One Stop are teaming up with CANDO, the Central Neighborhood Development Organization, to provide free hot meals to families affected by ICE activity. Find more info at the link; you can donate directly via Venmo, volunteer to deliver meals, or request a meal at moderntimes3200@gmail.com.

At Picnic Linden Hills, you can buy a hot meal for someone who needs it right now: teachers, community organizers, rapid responders, families in need. You buy the meal, the restaurant cooks it, volunteers deliver it. Here's how to nominate someone for a meal, and here's how to volunteer to deliver.

Dios Habla Hoy church in south Minneapolis, as mentioned above, has been an absolutely invaluable hub for food and essential good donations, packaging, and delivery. Here are full details on how to support, including direct donations and volunteering.

Joyce Uptown Foodshelf, which has done amazing work distributing groceries to families in need in the past few weeks, accepts food donations on Fridays from 9 a.m. to noon. They're taking a break on Friday January 23 due to the sub-zero temps, but will be back at it last week. And remember, as they say via their Facebook, there are many ways to support the food shelf: TLDR is cash is king, think long-term, and space out your donations.

Over in St. Paul, Zion Community Commons, Open Market MN, and the Twin Cities Vegan Chef Collective are working together to assemble “Shelter in Place” packs for families unable to leave their homes. You can find more information via Instagram.
Lowry Hill East Neighborhood Association (The Wedge) has an ongoing food share.
The Whittier Alliance is accepting donations specifically for rapid responders (like respirators, foot and hand warmers, safety goggles, YakTrax, etc.).
Not food, but the People's Laundry does laundry service mutual aid, you can volunteer!
For the sake of keeping this list manageable, I'm also going to link to Stand With Minnesota's list of food shelves (and check out the mutual aid section as well!).
Restaurants and Businesses to Support
One of the most-asked questions I’ve seen circulating on social media is: What businesses have been hit hardest by ICE’s presence, so we can support them?

In short, the answer is: immigrant-owned restaurants who have large immigrant customer bases. I can’t draft up an exact and comprehensive list, much as I wish I could, but I can give you a place to start based on some of my favorites:

•       Go for lunch at Mercado Central and get pupusas at Rincón Salvadoreño and apple turnovers from ground-floor bakery Panaderia El Mexicana; pick up a pressure cooker that’ll likely knock the socks off your Instant Pot.

•       For sweets: My favorites are rice pudding-filled doughnuts from Panaderia San Miguel; conchas and apricot-glazed hilos from Papá Chuy’s; halwo and vanilla cake from Albi Kitchen (also the sambusas here are great); malawax (sweet crepes) from Karmel Mall (yes, Hamdi is  excellent, but if you wander around the ground floor you’ll find a number of other stalls selling their own equally delicious versions).

•       For dinner: salmon and spaghetti at Mama Safia’s; smoky pozole from Habanero Tacos Street on Lake Street; Homi Restaurant’s entire caldos menu over in St. Paul; 18-inch, pastor-filled machetes from Taco Libre; fried tilapia and pilaf rice at Wiilo Restaurant & Bakery in Karmel Mall; pork belly gorditas at El Taco Torro in Midtown Global Market. For tacos: True Jalisco-style quesabirria at Taco Taxi; tacos de canasta at Las Charolas on the ground floor of Plaza Mexico and barbacoa de chivo at El Chivo Crazy just upstairs; tacos al pastor at Taqueria La Hacienda. If you’re feeding a crowd, Tacos El Primo does amazing catering-sized meals.
A key note, though. As you’re visiting and eating, please don’t take photos—given the very scary and inflammatory nature of the moment, doing so could potentially make staff or customers feel unsafe.
Restaurant Closures

Unfortunately, ICE’s presence throughout the metro has caused a number of restaurants and businesses to temporarily close to prioritize the safety and well-being of their employees. Because things are changing so fast, we're no longer listing those that are closing for a couple of days at a time or have changed their hours—there's simply too much to keep track of.
The below restaurants, though, are closed until further notice—the best way to support these places is to show up and eat there as soon as they reopen.
Valerie’s Carniceria and Alborada Market are now open after closing for several days, go shop there!
La Loma Tamales appears to have reopened at Mercado Central, while its 38th Street location remains closed.
After closing for a while, Casa Ibérica in Inver Grove Heights is reopen for pick-up and delivery.
Homi Restaurant in St. Paul is open but doing takeout only.
La Michoacana Monarca in St. Paul is set to open January 24.
Vive Tropico in Minneapolis is closed until further notice, but offering sweet treat kits for home delivery.
Both the Hopkins and Savage locations of Casa Deli are closed until further notice.
El Sazon Tacos & More in Eagan is closed until further notice.
Salsa a la Salsa in Midtown Global Market is closed until further notice.
Grande Sunrise Restaurant in St. Paul is closed until further notice (keep an eye on Facebook for details on how to support their employees).
Don Papi Chulo's in Inver Grove Heights is closed until further notice. You can donate to support them here.
Nachos Mexican Grill is closed until further notice. You can support them during their closure here.
The Shawarma Co. food truck is closed until further notice.
Machete Cocina Mexicana is closed until further notice; you can support their employee relief fund here.
All Los Ocampo locations are closed until further notice. You can support by buying merch and gift cards from their website and donating to their staff relief fund.
Xelas by El Sazon in Stillwater is closed until further notice after one of their employees was stopped (and then released) by ICE; you can support their staff relief fund here.
All three locations of Dancing Ganesha are closed until further notice.
Don Julio in White Bear Lake is closed until further notice.
Curry Corner is closed until further notice, you can support the restaurant here.
Don Pablo's in Detroit Lakes is closed until further notice.
Pajarito St. Paul location is closed until further notice, the Edina location remains open.
Pizzeria Lola is closed until further notice.
El Rodeo in Maple Grove is closed until further notice.
Restaurant Specials

Wrecktangle’s pizza fundraiser is over, but kudos to the team for distributing 600 (!!!) frozen pizzas, plus non-perishables and toiletries, to families in need. And also pulling off a massive food drive.
There's never been a better time to order a cold brew (no ice) from Workhorse Coffee Bar. A portion of proceeds will be donated to Minnesota Immigrant Rights Action Committee.
Sweet Lou’s Meats is using $5 gift cards to fundraise for MIRAC’s current food card drive.
Meteor Bar is running a daquiri special to support Immigrant Law Center and Immigrant Defense Network.

As of January 9, 10 percent of all sales at Mothership Pizza Paradise will go toward a fund supporting restaurant staff, and the restaurant has created a Venmo account where you can donate directly toward staff who are unable to work right now due to ICE’s presence in their neighborhood.

All you have to do is order a horchata and say "Abolish Ice" at Lito's Burritos on Lake Street and the full sales will go toward Minnesota Immigrant Rights Action Committee and other mutual aid efforts.
Order your cocktail with "No Ice" (though tbh you can probably still have ice if you want it) at EaTo and $2 from each purchase will support their employee support fund.

The Bungalow Club is hosting a pasta feed for neighbors on January 27—if you can contribute, great, if not, there's a meal there for you. They'll be collecting donations that will go directly to local mutual aid efforts. Doors open at 4 p.m., service continues until 8 p.m. or sold out.
All proceeds from Cafecito's pop-ups on January 31 and February 1 will support local mutual aid funds.
End of Mpls St Paul Magazine Article
